awd_titl_txt: A Sheaf-Theoretic Approach to M5-Brane Geometry
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This work studies connections between physics and mathematics.

It helps to begin our discussion by understanding the basic objects and quantities arising in physics, then to describe their mathematical counterparts.  We are familiar with an electron, and perhaps the fuzzy cloud it occupies around the nucleus of an atom.  The fuzziness is described quantitatively by a probability density, which gives the likelihood of finding the electron at different locations within the cloud. It is a mathematical function called a "wavefunction."  Heisenberg's uncertainty principle states we can describe the wavefunction with positions, or momenta, but not both at the same time --- so roughly half the coordinates are needed.  Mathematically, this means that the object to study is a "Lagrangian" subspace occupying half the dimensions of phase space.  The mathematical field which studies such things is symplectic geometry.  When the Lagrangian is infinite in extent, its asymptotic behavior defines a "Legendrian" subspace at infinity, which has the structure of a "contact manifold."

The upshot is that Legendrian and Lagrangian subspaces of contact and symplectic geometry are important for describing physical objects, and they are characterized by a wavefunction.

This is true of basic quantum physics, but also the theories of fundamental physics such as string theory and M-theory.  Over the past few decades, these theories have identified classes of Lagrangians to study.  These are called "branes," a word which is a variation of "membranes," which would be the case for two-dimensional objects.  In addition, several works have found ways of computing their wavefunctions.

In work supported by this grant, we developed methods to describe Lagrangian branes and compute their wavefunctions.  The methods to describe these spaces are graphical and concrete.  While the Lagrangians are three-dimensional objects living in six-dimensional space, their behavior at infinity is described by a two-dimensional Legendrian surface that can be thought of as living in three-dimensions, like sheets blowing in the wind on a clothesline.  The sheets of our surfaces can cross each other along a one-dimensional crossing locus, so ultimately the behavior is described by a network of line segments and nodes where the lines meet.  The description proves powerful --- able to establish new results about the number of three-dimensional spaces that can have the same surface as its boundary.

Different networks are related by certain moves called "mutations." These take the form of exchanging a piece of the network that looks like "H" with its four ends, by "I" with its four ends connected differently.  There is then a well-defined procedure to relate the wave functions for branes described by mutated graphs.

The upshot is that if you have a simple graph for which you know the brane wavefunction, you can deduce the wavefunctions of other branes.  These wavefunctions contain interesting information, and that is the payoff of the whole scheme.

The PI will continue to develop these methods in subsequence projects.
